title: Luffy's Eternal Pose Destruction as Series Philosophy
theory: Luffy's destruction of the Eternal Pose in Episode 67 represents a core philosophical principle that defines his entire journey. This moment establishes that Luffy values the journey and freedom of choice over shortcuts or predetermined paths. This philosophy is later reinforced in One Piece: Stampede when Luffy destroys an Eternal Pose to Laugh Tale, showing that even when offered a direct path to his ultimate goal, he refuses to compromise his values. The consistency of this choice across decades suggests it's not just character development but a fundamental thesis of One Piece: the journey matters more than the destination.
evidence: Luffy destroys the Eternal Pose to Arabasta in Episode 67 despite it offering a safer route
In Stampede, Luffy destroys an Eternal Pose to Laugh Tale, paralleling this moment
Luffy explicitly states 'You have no right to decide where we go'
Roger also threw away an Eternal Pose, as revealed in Stampede
The theme of forging one's own path recurs throughout the series

title: Robin Deliberately Sabotaged Her Own Offer
theory: Miss All Sunday's behavior in Episode 67 suggests she may have deliberately engineered the situation to fail. She offers the Eternal Pose knowing Luffy's personality, possibly testing the crew or ensuring they take the dangerous route that would inevitably lead to confrontation with Crocodile. Her calm acceptance when Luffy destroys the pose and her cryptic 'We'll meet again' suggests this outcome was expected or even desired. Some fans theorize she was already planning to betray Crocodile and wanted the Straw Hats to reach Arabasta via the route that would make them stronger opponents.
evidence: Robin shows no surprise or anger when Luffy destroys the Eternal Pose
Her mysterious smile and calm departure suggest a hidden agenda
She deliberately allowed Vivi to discover Mr. 0's identity earlier, setting events in motion
Later revelations show Robin was using Crocodile for her own purposes
Robin sparing Igaram (fake death) suggests she wasn't truly committed to Baroque Works' mission

title: Igaram's Survival Was Robin's Mercy
theory: While Robin claims to have destroyed Igaram's ship, evidence suggests she deliberately allowed him to survive. This act of mercy foreshadows her eventual betrayal of Baroque Works and hints at her underlying moral code. Fans theorize that Robin recognized Igaram's loyalty to Vivi and chose not to kill him, setting up explosives that appeared lethal but were survivable. This would align with Robin's character as someone who has been forced into villainy by circumstances rather than true malevolence.
evidence: Igaram survives the explosion and returns in Episode 130
Robin later shows she only used Crocodile for her own goals and wasn't truly evil
The explosion seemed designed more for spectacle than guaranteed lethality
Robin's character arc shows she values life despite her dark past
Unlike other Baroque Works agents, Robin shows restraint in violence

title: Robin's First Appearance Foreshadows Her Role as Crewmate
theory: Details in Robin's first appearance subtly foreshadow her eventual joining of the Straw Hat crew. Her mysterious behavior, the fact that she doesn't actually harm anyone despite claiming to be an antagonist, her interest in Luffy's determination, and her cryptic farewell all plant seeds for her later recruitment. Unlike other antagonists who are defeated and overcome, Robin simply observes and departs, suggesting from the start that she occupies a different narrative role than a traditional villain.
evidence: Robin doesn't actually attack the crew despite having opportunity and motive
She shows interest in Luffy's character when he destroys the Eternal Pose
Her departure is peaceful rather than antagonistic
She says 'We'll meet again' suggesting future alliance rather than enmity
The animation/direction treats her more mysteriously than threateningly
She later joins the crew in Episode 130, fulfilling the foreshadowing
